title.narrative: Oxfam-IBIS Support Mechanism for Indigenous Peoples, "Oxlajuj Tz'ikin" 2019-2023

description.narrative:
Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The indigenous peoples of Guatemala are subject to racism, discrimination and social, economic and political marginalization, which among other things has led to significantly higher poverty and illiteracy among indigenous peoples compared to the rest of the population, indigenous peoples have the lowest social indicators in the country.
"The programme for indigenous people's rights" is implementeded by Oxfam-Ibis together with 16 partner organizations aims to contribute to the exercise of the individual and collective rights, and self-determination of indigenous people in accordance with international agreements. The programme will cover 11 of Guatemala's 22 administrative regions (Totonicapán, Sololá, Quetzaltenango, Alta and Baja Verapaz, Quiche, Santa Rosa, Jutiapa, Jalapa, Chimaltenango and Guatemala City). These areas are highly affected by poverty and exclusion.
The Swedish contribution will be used for activities aimed at strengthening knowledge and exercise of individual and collective rights as well as strengthening the capacities of the partner organisations. Legal support will be provided through the project to support indigenous people to claim their rights as established in national legislation and international agreements. The indigenous justice system will be strengthened in order to ensure equal justice for women and men. Through the facilitation of a dialogue for the integration of a gender perspective in work with indigenous authorities women’s participation in decision-making processes is expected to increase. Work with men and boys will be used as a strategy to prevent violence against women, teenage pregnancies and child marriages. As a conflict prevention measure, indigenous organizations will be supported in improving their capacity to deal with internal conflicts within their own communities, and for stronger influence on social issues, relationships with state institutions at local and national level will be supported.
The project will have a strong focus on alliance building with other civil society organisations, state and academic institutions, as well as with the UN Human Rights Office to further strengthen the implementation and sustainability of the results. In this work, actors defending human rights are expected to work together in areas such as the environment and climate, access to justice and gender equality for an increased impact.
Oxfam-IBIS has applied to Sida for funding of 60 million SEK to carry out the project in Guatemala during the period during November 2019 - April 2023. The project's total budget is 66.3 million SEK, out of which 6.3 million SEK is financed by DANIDA. Approximately 44 million SEK (66%) of the project budget will be forwarded to 16 local indigenous organizations.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Urfolken i Guatemala är utsatta för rasism, diskriminering och social, ekonomisk och politisk marginalisering vilket bland annat har lett till betydande högre fattigdom och analfabetism bland urfolk jämfört med resten av befolkningen, urfolk har de lägsta sociala indikatorerna i landet.
"Programmet för urfolksrättigheter" genomförs av Oxfam-Ibis tillsammans med 16 partnerorganisationer och syftar till att bidra till utövandet av urfolks individuella och kollektiva rättigheter, samt självbestämmande i enlighet med internationella överenskommelser. Programmet kommer att täcka 11 av landets 22 regiondepartement (Totonicapán, Sololá, Quetzaltenango, Alta och Baja Verapaz, Quiche, Santa Rosa, Jutiapa, Jalapa, Chimaltenango och Guatemala City. Dessa områden påverkas starkt av fattigdom och exkludering.
Det svenska bidraget kommer att användas för aktiviteter som syftar till att stärka kunskapen om och utövandet av individuella och kollektiva rättigheter samt stärka partnerorganisationernas kapacitet. I projektet ingår juridiskt stöd för att urfolk ska kunna kräva sina rättigheter enligt nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal. Även urfolks eget rättssystem kommer att stärkas för att säkerställa jämställd rättvisa mellan kvinnor och män. Genom att underlätta dialog för integrering av ett jämställdhetsperspektiv i arbetet med urfolksmyndigheter förväntas kvinnors deltagande i beslutsprocesser öka. Arbete med män och pojkar kommer att användas som strategi för att förebygga våld mot kvinnor, tonårsgraviditeter och barnäktenskap. I konfliktförebyggande syfte kommer urfolksorganisationer stödjas i att förbättra sin kapacitet att hantera interna konflikter inom sina egna samhällen, och för stärkt inflytande i samhällsfrågor kommer relationsbyggande med statliga institutioner på lokal och nationell nivå stödjas.
Projektet kommer att ha ett starkt fokus på alliansbyggande med andra civilsamhällesorganisationer, statliga och akademiska institutioner, samt med FN's kontor för mänskliga rättigheter för att ytterligare stärka genomförandet och hållbarheten i resultaten. Inom detta arbete förväntas aktörer som försvarar de mänskliga rättigheterna organisera sig för större genomslag inom områden som till exempel miljö- och klimat, tillgång till rättvisa och jämställdhet.
Oxfam-IBIS har ansökt om finansiering av 60 miljoner kr för att genomföra projektet i Guatemala under perioden november 2019 - april 2023. Projektets totala budget är 66,3 miljoner kr, varav 6,3 miljoner kr finansieras av DANIDA. Cirka 44 miljoner kr (66%) av projektbudgeten vidareförmedlas till 16 lokala urfolksorganisationer.

The overall objective of the project is to promote the exercise of indigenous peoples' individual and collective rights in accordance with international standards, and to strengthen the ability of indigenous people to contribute to the development and implementation of national laws, institutional frameworks and public policies.

tag.narrative: 1.2 - By 2030, reduce at least by half the proportion of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions.
1.2 - Till 2030 minst halvera den andel män, kvinnor och barn i alla åldrar som lever i någon form av fattigdom enligt nationella definitioner.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.

description.narrative: The “Oxlajuj Tz'ikin Indigenous Peoples Support Mechanism” project iniciated in November 2019 and during this period Oxfam-Ibis has entered into agreements with 12 of 16 local indigenous organizations. In April 2020, Sida approved a minor adjustment in the budget and plan due to Covid -19. Some activities have been changed, others have been divided in small groups and others have been postponed or changed into virtual activities. 1. With regards to women’s participation in decision-making spaces and women’s access to justice in the official legal system and the indigenous justice system, the contribution has continued promoting strategic alliances with indigenous women’s organizations and indigenous authorities, advocating in decision-making structures. 2. The project has made progress advocating on different policy issues on a national, departmental, and municipal level, including education policy, compensation, women’s affairs, youth policy, and others. New youth training processes have been launched, and scholarships awarded for primary school, secondary school, and high school education to strengthen youth participation in community decision-making spaces. The project has also monitored individual and collective compensation processes, and a municipal women’s policy was approved. 3. The process of reconstitution of indigenous authorities has expanded and gained strength in this quarter. The most important of these processes are implemented in the Los Copones region, and in different municipalities around the department of Sololá, where the community enrollment and capacity-building process continues, with the creation of strategic alliances through exchange and implementation of joint agendas.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
